item.title: Rethinking protein: Doctors call for balanced nutrition, highlight risks of overconsumption - The Times of India
item.description:
Rethinking Protein: Doctors Call for Balanced Nutrition, Highlight Risks of Overconsumption

Publication Date: [Insert Date] | Source: [Insert Source]

This article discusses the importance of balanced nutrition with a focus on protein consumption. Medical professionals highlight the potential health risks associated with excessive protein intake.

  • Calls for a shift in dietary recommendations concerning protein consumption.
  • Emphasizes the health risks associated with overconsumption of protein.
  • Advises on the importance of a well-rounded diet including various nutrients.
  • Supports the idea of individualized nutrition plans tailored to personal health needs.
"Overconsumption of protein can lead to various health issues that may not be immediately apparent."

In conclusion, health experts urge for a reevaluation of dietary guidelines to ensure that protein is consumed in moderation as part of a balanced diet.

item.title: Boost your health this winter with these nutrient-rich exotic fruits - India Today
item.description:
Boost Your Health This Winter with Nutrient-Rich Exotic Fruits

Published On: Jan 13, 2025

Source: indiatodayglobal

This winter, explore exotic fruits like guava, kumquat, kiwi, persimmons, and pomegranate to boost nutrition and add vibrant flavours to your diet. These unique options offer health benefits and exciting tastes.

  • Guava is rich in vitamin C, fiber, and antioxidants.
  • Kumquats can be eaten whole; they have a sweet peel and a tart flesh.
  • Kiwi is packed with vitamin C, fiber, and potassium, offering a sweet-tart flavor.
  • Star fruit presents a unique shape and mild flavor, high in vitamin C.
  • Persimmons come in two varieties, both offering vitamins A and C.
  • Pomelo is milder than grapefruit and rich in nutrients.
  • Pomegranate is loaded with antioxidants and adds flavor to dishes.
“These unusual fruits provide winter diets with variation and variety and also introduce an array of health benefits.”

Incorporating these fruits into your winter diet can enhance both your health and culinary experience. Don’t miss the opportunity to try these exotic options for a more vibrant and nutrient-rich winter.

item.title: HMPV outbreak: Amid global concern, Chinese official says cases in northern China declining - India TV News
item.description:
HMPV outbreak: Cases in Northern China Declining Amid Global Concern

Publication Date: Not specified | Source: Not specified

The rate of infections with the flu-like human metapneumovirus (HMPV) in northern China is declining, according to a health official, amidst international concern over a potential pandemic.

  • The recent outbreak of HMPV has raised alarms similar to COVID-19 due to images of overwhelmed hospitals.
  • The virus has been present for decades, and most children contract it by age 5.
  • Symptoms include fever, cough, and nasal congestion, usually resolving on their own.
  • Current trends show declining rates of positive cases, especially among patients aged 14 and below.
  • No vaccines or specific treatments are available for HMPV; preventive measures are advised.
“The human metapneumovirus is not a new virus, and has been with humans for at least several decades.” - Wang Liping, Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention

The situation appears manageable with no significant medical resource shortages reported. Experts express cautious optimism as flu infections are expected to decline in the coming weeks.

item.title: 7 morning shots that help burn fat and reduce weight - The Times of India
item.description:
7 Morning Shots to Burn Fat and Reduce Weight

Publication Date: Jan 12, 2025 | Source: TimesOfIndia.com

Starting your day with the right drink can significantly impact your weight loss journey. Morning shots are small, power-packed drinks that can boost metabolism, improve digestion, and help burn fat. Here are 7 weight-loss-friendly shots tailored for an Indian lifestyle.

  • Lemon and Honey Shot: A metabolism booster made with lemon juice and honey in warm water.
  • Jeera Water Shot: A traditional remedy using soaked cumin seeds to aid digestion and weight loss.
  • Amla Shot: A drink made from fresh amla, rich in vitamin C, to enhance metabolism and immunity.
  • Cinnamon and Honey Shot: A combination that helps regulate blood sugar and curb cravings.
  • Ginger and Lemon Shot: A zesty drink that stimulates metabolism and improves digestion.
  • Methi Water Shot: Fenugreek water to suppress appetite and balance blood sugar levels.
  • Turmeric and Black Pepper Shot: A drink promoting weight loss and overall wellness with curcumin.
"Pair these shots with a balanced diet and regular exercise for the best results."

Incorporating these simple shots into your morning routine can provide a boost to your weight loss goals.

item.title: Explained: How to protect yourself from norovirus, Covid-19, flu, and RSV - Business Standard
item.description:
How to Protect Yourself from Norovirus, COVID-19, Flu, and RSV

Date: October 2023 | Source: Business Standard

In the winter months, many are susceptible to illnesses such as flu and COVID-19. Understanding how these viruses spread and how to protect oneself is vital for health during this season.

  • Norovirus is spread through contaminated surfaces and can lead to vomiting and diarrhea.
  • Common cold symptoms include a runny nose and sore throat, while flu symptoms can be more intense.
  • COVID-19 can lead to severe respiratory symptoms and loss of taste or smell.
  • Handwashing is crucial in preventing the spread of these viruses.
  • Cleaning surfaces and self-isolation if symptomatic are recommended practices.
  • Vaccines are available for COVID-19 and flu, but not for norovirus.
“If you do get sick, prompt testing can help determine whether you have COVID-19 or influenza.”

Maintaining good hygiene and staying informed can help mitigate the risks associated with these viruses during the winter months.

item.title: California man dies from an unusual lung cancer spread from another person - The Times of India
item.description:
California man dies from an unusual lung cancer spread from another person

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Unknown

A California man has tragically passed away due to a rare form of lung cancer that was transmitted from another person, highlighting the potential for cancer to be spread in ways not previously understood.

  • The lung cancer in question is particularly unusual and raises questions about transmission methods.
  • Medical experts call for further research into the mechanisms of cancer spread.
  • This incident has sparked discussions about public health and cancer awareness.
"This case underscores the necessity for increased awareness and understanding of how lung cancer can manifest in unexpected ways."

This event illuminates the need for continued research in cancer transmission and awareness in public health practices.

item.title: Addicted to reels? It can cause high blood pressure, hypertension, finds study - Moneycontrol
item.description:
Addicted to reels? It can cause high blood pressure, hypertension, finds study

Date: January 12, 2025 / Source: Moneycontrol

Recent research indicates a correlation between watching social media reels at bedtime and hypertension among young and middle-aged individuals in China.

  • The study surveyed 4,318 participants, revealing increased susceptibility to high blood pressure with more screen time on reels.
  • Findings were shared by cardiologist Dr. Deepak Krishnamurthy, emphasizing reel addiction as a major health risk.
  • The study suggests that watching reels before sleep contributes to sympathetic arousal, heightening blood pressure risks.
  • Researchers recommend limiting screen time while maintaining a healthy lifestyle to prevent hypertension.
Apart from being a major distraction and waste of time, reel addiction is also associated with high #BloodPressure in young and middle-aged people. Time to #UnInsta!!

Overall, the study raises awareness about the health implications of excessive screen time, especially during bedtime, highlighting the need for moderation and lifestyle adjustments.

item.title: More children test positive for mumps in Alappuzha - The Hindu
item.description:
More children test positive for mumps in Alappuzha

Date: January 12, 2025 Source: Local Health Report

The Alappuzha district is currently experiencing a rise in mumps infections among school students, prompting health officials to take action.

  • At least five students at Eramalloor and four at Punnapra have tested positive.
  • The total infections at Eramalloor school have risen to 28, including a previous outbreak affecting 23 students.
  • Schools in the area have been closed for 21 days due to the outbreak.
  • Surveillance and preventive measures have been intensified by health department officials.
  • Mumps is primarily a disease in children but can also affect adolescents and adults, causing swelling of the salivary glands.
Mumps is a contagious disease caused by a virus that primarily affects children but could also infect adolescents and adults.

This outbreak of mumps highlights the importance of vaccination and public health measures to control infectious diseases among school-aged children.

item.title: Ice Baths for Stress: New research says cold water could sharpen your mind and improve sleep - The Times of India
item.description:
Ice Baths for Stress: New research says cold water could sharpen your mind and improve sleep

Publication Date: Date not provided
Source: Source not provided

This article explores the potential benefits of ice baths on mental sharpness and sleep quality based on new research findings.

  • Recent studies suggest that cold water exposure may have positive effects on cognitive function.
  • Ice baths are gaining popularity among individuals seeking to improve their sleep patterns.
  • Research indicates that cold water therapy could enhance resilience to stress.
"Cold exposure has been linked to improved mood and cognitive clarity."

The findings suggest that incorporating ice baths into one's routine might not only be beneficial for physical recovery but also for mental health.

item.title: 14,700 confirmed mpox cases reported in 2024 in Africa: WHO - Yes Punjab
item.description:
14,700 confirmed mpox cases reported in 2024 in Africa: WHO

Date: January 12, 2025
Source: Yes Punjab News

About 14,700 confirmed mpox cases, including 66 deaths, were reported in 20 African countries from January 2024 to January 5, 2025, the World Health Organization (WHO) said.

  • The confirmed cases represent only a subset of suspected cases, with many remaining untested due to limited diagnostic capacity.
  • The outbreak is driven by multiple clades of the virus, especially the Clade Ib variant, which is spreading predominantly in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC).
  • Imported mpox cases from travel have been detected outside Africa, primarily among adults who traveled during their incubation periods.
  • The ongoing outbreak was declared a public health emergency of continental security by the Africa CDC in mid-August 2024.
  • The WHO activated its highest level of global alert for mpox, marking the second time in two years.
“We urge member states to sustain and strengthen mpox surveillance to improve case detection and reporting.” - WHO

Mpox, also known as monkeypox, is a rare viral disease that spreads through body fluids, respiratory droplets, and contaminated materials, causing symptoms like fever and rash.

item.title: Fibre may help protect your gut from overgrowth of harmful bugs: Study - The Indian Express
item.description:
Fibre May Protect Gut Health Against Harmful Bacteria: New Study

Publication Date: (Date not provided), Source: Indian Express

This new study reveals how a healthy gut environment, influenced by diet, can inhibit harmful bacteria such as Enterobacteriaceae, offering insights into gut health management.

  • The study analyzed over 12,000 stool samples globally, indicating a strong link between gut microbiome composition and the presence of harmful bacteria.
  • Fatty acids produced by bacteria like Faecalibacterium are crucial in preventing the overgrowth of harmful microbes.
  • Co-colonisers of harmful bacteria demonstrate adaptability, suggesting that gut conditions play a significant role in bacterial survival.
  • Findings may lead to alternative methods for preventing infections without antibiotics by promoting beneficial bacteria instead.
  • The research highlights the need for further studies on global microbiome diversity and its implications for health.
“Instead of killing harmful bacteria directly, we could boost the co-excluders or create diets that support their growth.”

This research underscores the importance of dietary fibres in maintaining gut health and could pave the way for new treatments targeting harmful bacteria.

item.title: HMPV cases in northern China declining, says country's health official - Hindustan Times
item.description:
HMPV cases in northern China declining, says country's health official

Date: Jan 12, 2025 Source: Hindustan Times

The Chinese health authorities have reported a decline in human metapneumovirus (HMPV) cases, alleviating concerns amid a global focus on respiratory illnesses.

  • HMPV is a frequent respiratory virus causing mild symptoms similar to a cold.
  • China stated recent increases in case detection were due to improved detection methods, not a new surge of the virus.
  • Research indicates that many adults have immunity, but the virus is more severe in infants or immunocompromised individuals.
  • Reports of hospitals being overwhelmed have not been verified; WHO noted no unusual outbreaks.
  • No vaccines or specific treatments are available for HMPV.
“At present, the rate of positive cases in human metapneumovirus detection is fluctuating, and the rate of positive cases in northern provinces is declining,” - Wang Liping.

Overall, the situation appears to be under control, with no significant shortages of medical resources reported.

item.title: 8 vitamins and minerals that are lost in cooking (and how to retain them) - The Times of India
item.description:
8 Vitamins and Minerals That Are Lost in Cooking (And How to Retain Them)

Publication Date: Jan 12, 2025 | Source: Times of India

Cooking enhances flavor, texture, and digestibility of food, but it can also cause significant nutrient loss. Heat, water, and cooking duration can degrade essential vitamins and minerals, potentially diminishing their health benefits. Here’s a list of eight vital nutrients that are most vulnerable and tips to preserve them.

  • Vitamin C: Sensitive to heat; steam or microwave instead of boiling.
  • Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Diminished through prolonged cooking; use shorter cooking times.
  • Folate (Vitamin B9): Degrades rapidly; prefer steaming or raw options.
  • Potassium: Loss occurs through leaching; use minimal water in cooking.
  • Vitamin B6: Degraded during high-heat cooking; choose raw or lightly cooked foods.
  • Iron: Availability may decrease; soak or sprout grains and legumes.
  • Calcium: Lost due to oxalate binding; opt for low-oxalate greens.
  • Magnesium: Lost in water; prefer steaming or roasting.
“Cooking enhances flavor, but can cause nutrient loss.”

The article emphasizes the importance of cooking methods in nutrient retention, encouraging healthier practices to ensure essential vitamins and minerals are preserved for better health.

item.title: Gut microbiome's role in fighting infections: Study reveals how diet can impact risk - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Gut Microbiome's Role in Fighting Infections: Study Reveals Dietary Impact

Posted on: Jan 12, 2025 | Source: ANI

A new study highlights how the composition of the gut microbiome can predict susceptibility to infections like Klebsiella pneumoniae and E.coli, suggesting that increasing fiber intake can enhance protection against these harmful bacteria.

  • The gut microbiome may influence the risk of potentially life-threatening infections.
  • Research analyzed stool samples from over 12,000 people worldwide to study gut microbiome signatures.
  • Fibers in diet promote beneficial gut bacteria that can fend off harmful bacteria.
  • Probiotics are less effective than dietary changes in altering gut health.
“Our results suggest that what we eat is potentially very important in controlling the likelihood of infection with a range of bacteria, including E.coli and Klebsiella pneumoniae because this changes our gut environment to make it more hostile to invaders.” - Dr Alexandre Almeida

The findings point to the significance of dietary choices in promoting gut health and reducing the risk of serious infections.

item.title: HMPV infection rate in northern China declines: Chinese health official - Business Standard
item.description:
HMPV Infection Rates Decline in Northern China

Publication Date: Sunday

Source: Business Standard

Health officials have reported a decline in infections of the human metapneumovirus (HMPV) in northern China, alleviating some international pandemic concerns. HMPV, while flu-like, is known to clear up on its own but can lead to more severe respiratory issues in vulnerable populations.

  • The rate of HMPV infections is decreasing in northern provinces.
  • Recent concerns were raised over a surge in cases, but the World Health Organization reports no unusual outbreaks.
  • Built-in immunity from prior exposure is noted, especially in children.
  • No new infectious diseases have emerged in China; current respiratory issues are caused by known pathogens.
“There is no obvious shortage of medical resources,” said Gao Xinqiang, deputy director of the Department of Medical Emergency Response.

Experts advise regular hand washing and masking in crowded places as precautions.

item.title: Morning Coffee Timing Linked to Longer Life and Better Heart Health - SciTechDaily
item.description:
Morning Coffee Timing Linked to Longer Life and Better Heart Health

Publication Date: January 8, 2025 | Source: European Heart Journal

Drinking coffee in the morning is associated with a lower risk of cardiovascular disease and overall mortality compared to drinking coffee all day, according to a comprehensive study published in the European Heart Journal.

  • The study tracked the coffee consumption habits of over 40,000 adults.
  • Morning coffee drinkers were 16% less likely to die of any cause and 31% less likely to die of cardiovascular disease compared to non-coffee drinkers.
  • Those who drank coffee throughout the day did not show reduced risks.
  • A possible explanation may relate to circadian rhythms disrupted by afternoon or evening coffee.
“This is the first study testing coffee drinking timing patterns and health outcomes. Our findings indicate that it’s not just whether you drink coffee or how much you drink, but the time of day when you drink coffee that’s important.” - Dr. Lu Qi

In conclusion, the timing of coffee consumption may be as important as the amount consumed, suggesting a possible avenue for improving heart health.

item.title: Rate of HMPV infections in northern China declining: Health official - The Times of India
item.description:
Rate of HMPV infections in northern China declining: Health official

Date: [Insert Publication Date] | Source: [Insert Source]

The health official reports a decline in the rate of Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV) infections in northern China, indicating positive trends in public health.

  • HMPV cases are decreasing in northern China.
  • The health department emphasizes continued monitoring and prevention measures.
  • Potential links to vaccination or effective public health interventions are being explored.
"Our ongoing efforts in public health are yielding positive results as we see a decline in infections."

The decline in HMPV infections is a promising sign, but health officials stress the importance of vigilance and continued public health efforts.

item.title: US gov’t report finds even 1 drink a day elevates cancer risk. Here’s an expert’s analysis. - Rappler
item.description:
US Gov't Report Finds Daily Alcohol Consumption Raises Cancer Risk

Publication Date: January 3, 2025 | Source: Rappler

A new report from the US surgeon general reveals that even one alcoholic drink a day is linked to an increased risk of several cancers. This advisory aims to raise awareness about the dangers of alcohol consumption.

  • Alcohol is the third-most preventable cause of cancer in the US.
  • The report features a call for new cancer warning labels on alcoholic beverages.
  • Approximately 100,000 cancer cases and 20,000 cancer deaths annually are associated with alcohol use.
  • Less than half of Americans view alcohol as a cancer risk factor according to surveys.
  • The risk is particularly notable for breast, liver, and colorectal cancers.
  • The report emphasizes the importance of informing the public about alcohol's cancer risks.
“Alcohol is associated with approximately 100,000 cancer cases and 20,000 cancer deaths every year.”

This advisory represents a significant effort to combat alcohol-related health issues and promote healthier lifestyles among Americans.

item.title: HMPV virus: How doctors are using social media, humour to educate people | Mint - Mint
item.description:
HMPV virus: How doctors are using social media, humour to educate people

Publication Date: [Insert Date] | Source: Mint

As cases of HMPV (human metapneumovirus) emerge globally, doctors are leveraging social media and humor to calm public fears and educate about the virus.

  • HMPV cases reported in China sparked widespread panic, especially in Asia.
  • India has confirmed 13 cases, including a recent case in a 9-month-old child from Gujarat.
  • Medical professionals emphasize that HMPV is not a cause for mass panic.
“The HMPV virus needn’t be a cause for panic or anxiety.”

This initiative aims to educate the public in a more accessible and relatable manner amidst rising fears of respiratory viruses.

item.title: The price of protection: tackling inequity in cervical cancer prevention - The Hindu
item.description:
The Price of Protection: Tackling Inequity in Cervical Cancer Prevention

Published on: January 12, 2025, Source: The Hindu

No woman should die from cervical cancer. Yet, it is the second leading cancer and significant contributor to cancer-related deaths in Indian women. Despite being one of the most preventable and curable cancers, the cervical screening rate in India is dismal at 2%.

  • Cervical cancer is primarily caused by the Human Papilloma Virus (HPV), which affects 99% of cases.
  • Vaccines are available, but their high cost makes them inaccessible to many women, especially in low-income areas.
  • Screening and vaccination strategies are central to preventing cervical cancer and its serious consequences.
  • The WHO recommends regular screening and vaccination as effective public health strategies.
  • There is a need for increased public health education and awareness to bridge the gap in cervical cancer prevention.

“Implementing the WHO strategy could prevent 60 million cervical cancer cases and 45 million deaths over the next 100 years.”

This urgent issue highlights the significance of ensuring equitable access to vaccinations and screening for cervical cancer to protect women's health.

item.title: Experts share simple tips to beat joint pain this winter - Nottinghamshire Live
item.description:
Experts Share Simple Tips to Beat Joint Pain This Winter

Publication Date: [Insert Date] Source: [Insert Source]

An estimated 10 million people in the UK suffer from osteoarthritis, with winter worsening joint pain for many due to colder temperatures and weather conditions. Experts provide advice on managing these symptoms effectively.

  • Many individuals report that cold weather exacerbates joint pain.
  • Research shows a correlation between joint pain and temperature drops.
  • Activities such as yoga and swimming can help keep joints flexible.
  • Healthy eating and maintaining Vitamin D levels are crucial.
  • Some patients consider medical cannabis as an alternative treatment.
"As winter approaches, I know exactly when the temperature is going to drop because the osteoarthritis in my hands is so painful." - Raija Piispanen

To manage joint pain in winter, experts recommend staying warm, exercising, and considering dietary supplements.

item.title: Elderly man from Kutch tested HMPV positive making Gujarat’s fifth case - Gujarat Samachar
item.description:
Elderly Man in Kutch Tests Positive for HMPV, Increasing Gujarat's Cases to Five

Publication Date: Jan 12th, 2025 | Source: Gujarat Samachar

A 59-year-old man from Kutch has been confirmed with Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV) in Ahmedabad, marking the fifth reported case in Gujarat.

  • The patient, who has no travel history, is receiving treatment at Zydus Hospital in Ahmedabad.
  • Previous cases include a 2-month-old infant and an 8-year-old child, highlighting the virus's spread among vulnerable populations.
  • The Gujarat government has issued health advisories to prevent further spread of the virus, emphasizing precautions during winter.
  • HMPV, first detected in 2001, typically resembles cold or flu symptoms and usually doesn't require hospitalization.
Experts suggest, 'Most HMPV cases do not require hospitalization, and there’s no need to panic.'

The health department stresses the importance of following safety measures to limit respiratory infections, particularly in the upcoming winter months.

item.title: Fibre may help protect your gut from overgrowth of harmful bugs Study - The Week
item.description:
Fibre May Help Protect Your Gut from Harmful Bacteria

Updated: January 12, 2025 | Source: The Conversation

This article discusses a recent study exploring how gut bacteria protect against harmful microbes like Enterobacteriaceae, emphasizing the role of dietary fibers in promoting beneficial bacteria.

  • A new study published in Nature Microbiology examined how certain gut bacteria can ward off harmful ones.
  • The research analyzed over 12,000 stool samples from 45 countries.
  • Key findings included the identification of co-colonisers and co-excluders among gut bacteria.
  • Faecalibacterium is highlighted as a crucial co-excluder that produces beneficial short-chain fatty acids.
  • The findings suggest new approaches to prevent infections without antibiotics by enhancing co-excluders through diet.
“By better understanding how microbes interact and communicate in our gut, we can develop more precise, non-antibiotic therapies to protect against infections in the future.”

In conclusion, understanding the dynamics of gut bacteria could lead to more effective ways to manage gut health without relying on antibiotics.

item.title: 14,700 confirmed mpox cases reported in 2024 in Africa: WHO - Tripuratimes
item.description:
14,700 confirmed mpox cases reported in 2024 in Africa: WHO

Date: January 12, 2025 Source: tripuratimes

As of January 5, 2025, approximately 14,700 confirmed mpox cases, including 66 fatalities, have been reported across 20 African nations. These figures highlight the ongoing challenges in accurately diagnosing and reporting cases of mpox.

  • The outbreak is primarily driven by various clades of the mpox virus, especially the Clade Ib variant.
  • Significant gaps in diagnostic capabilities exist in countries like the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC).
  • Travel-related cases of mpox have emerged outside Africa, complicating surveillance efforts.
  • The outbreak was declared a public health emergency by both the Africa CDC and WHO.
“WHO urged member states to sustain and strengthen mpox surveillance to improve case detection and reporting.”

This situation underscores the need for enhanced surveillance and the allocation of resources to effectively manage and control mpox outbreaks in African countries.
